Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 03:42PM hmm wrote: 4thefather, I did radiation treatments ( 30 of them) during November and December............. the first two weeks I was more tired than I was for the remainder of them. I kept up with walking 2 to 4 miles daily and as they advised kept hydrated. So maybe too you will find it easier as the weeks continue. They did stress the importance of both exercising and drinking enough. But during those first two weeks I kept thinking about the fact that I was so very tired and how awful it would be within another week or two........................... this did not happen I am happy to say. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: I just don't get it! 4thefather 4thefather

Posts.Title: My Surgeon never told me tamlyn110 PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 12:03PM hmm wrote: Yes........ I had a similar experience. I was diagnosed in Sept 08 and had surgery the beginning of October followed by radiation. My first after surgery mammogram was in March and they also did a sonogram. Then.......... they wanted to do the MRI which they did and all was okay. I think between the surgery and the radiation there are "changes" and they are checking to make sure that is the case. At the time I too was very upset and can totally relate. Hope this was helpful and if you have any questions just let me know. Best wishes and hugs to you, Pat

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 08:05PM hmm wrote: Debbie, The rads were "okay" but I "almost" backed out as I was having second thoughts about any possible long lasting side effects from them. In order to give myself the best chances with this I either had to do the rads or have a mast. So after having a meeting with the rad. onc. decided to go ahead with the rads. From time to time ( usually when going for mammos etc) I second guess my decision!!!! Everyone is different and we all have to do what is right for us. Let me know what you decide........ good luck!!!! Pat
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 09:38PM - edited Nov 6, 2009 09:46PM by hmm Debbie, To answer your question about the radiation onc.............. he gave me percentages on possible risk of side effects from the radiation. These were for the serious ones like heart damage which ended up not being an issue as it was my right breast that had rads. So one by one we went over any other possible things that could happen which of course I had asked Dr. Goggle and when I realized the percentages were very low I went with it. Plus I was not wanting more surgery at the time. However......................... many times I think ............hmmmm why did I not just do it!!!!! Meaning of course mast. with reconstruction!!!!  With the radiaiton itself I did not have any problems ........my skin just got pinkish and then a bronze color but nothing bad. Used lotions 3 or 4 times a day and stayed hydrated as they said to. So it was okay...or as okay as these things can be. Hope this was of some help. Pat

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 08:58PM - edited Jan 7, 2010 09:28PM by hmm Cake- Sorry to read about your friend's friend............totally agree that it is not fair. October is usually still pretty warm if not hot in Orlando. Between when the children go back to school and Thanksgiving is one of the slower times so that should work very well for you. Sometimes when it is very busy the wait times are such that it takes way too long to do the different things and most likely you won't have to deal too much with that. As for Universal it is actually two parks................... the one with all the thrill rides is called Islands of Adventure............the other is Universal Studios and that does not have the thrill rides. As for the Space Center you may want to go to their web and decide for yourself as you know what your children enjoy. It will be such fun! Pat
